description.narrative:
The world is experiencing the biggest displacement crisis since the end of the 2nd World War with more than 65 million people estimated to have been forced to flee their home due to conflict, violence and persecution. Many millions more have fled their homes fromenvironmental disasters or set off in search of safer, more sustainable futures in attempts to leave behind situations of inequality, instability, generalised violence, and human rights abuses. While the most prevalent media images of displacement are of people undertaking arduous journeys over land and sea, the experience of both internal and cross-border displacement for millions of people is better characterised by constraints on mobility. Although a decreasing number of refugees are confined to camps, those living in urban settings often have limited access to humanitarian assistance and restrictions on joining the (regulated) labour market are inevitably pushing people into situations of exploitation. Many internally displaced persons (IDPs) face similar circumstances.
T he governance of global migration is dominated by the perceived political interests of rich, ‘destination’ countries, propped up by popular sentiment that perceives migrants as a threat. By restricting borders, pushing-back boats, and building higher fences to keep people out, or forcibly returning them before it is safe to do so, governments are not only failing people in desperate need of protection but also further "displacing the challenge" of migration management and the provision of protection to other countries. While governments around the world contribute to the drivers of displacement, including by exacerbating conflicts, the real crisis is their failure to uphold core tenets of international law – e.g. the right to claim asylum, provide humanitarian assistance – and their failure to share responsibility for displaced people. This results in developing countries – and poor communities within these countries - more often than not paying the price, and displaced people remaining displaced for their lifetimes. Oxfam, including Oxfam Novib, works to address the drivers of displacement and migration (including conflict, disaster, climate change and economic inequality) as well as challenging the concept that mobility should be the preserve of the rich.

participating-org.narrative: Oxfam Novib was founded in 1956 as the Netherlands Organisation for International Assistance (Novib), and joined forces with Oxfam in 1994. Oxfam Novib is member of the Oxfam International confederation. Working together in the confederation, the Oxfam affiliates can speak with one clear and compelling voice on issues of global concern: climate change, health and education for all, agriculture, trade, and conflicts and emergencies. Oxfam Novib's main office is based in The Netherlands, it supports the work of a network of local offices, the implementation of global projects, fundraising, campaigning and advocacy. Oxfam Novib’s the Hague office contributes towards this project’s implementation.

mailing-address.narrative: PO box 30919, 2500 GX The Hague, The Netherlands
